title: Ticket #4700: Document how to restart DAGMan in recovery mode
description:
We don't really document how to re-start DAGMan in recovery mode. A situation where you might need to do this is as follows: the filesystem that your dagman.out file is on fills up while DAGMan is running, causing dprintf to fail, which makes DAGMan exit. In this case, I believe that DAGMan will exit the queue, and we don't document how the user should re-submit it without re-running the jobs that already succeeded.

If the user just does "condor_submit_dag <dag_file>" I think it will complain about the .condor.sub file, etc., already existing. So they may end up doing condor_submit_dag -f, which will re-run all jobs. They can do the right thing by doing "condor_submit <dag_file>.condor_sub", but I can't remember whether "condor_submit_dag -recovery <dag_file>" will work.

(I think you can kind of simulate this by removing a DAG that's already on hold.)
remarks:
2015-Feb-03 15:19:00 by smoler:
In fact, we never document what 'recovery' is. So, this ticket will also cover the task of generating a new subsection of the DAGMan documentation that discusses recovery in general, as well as identifying how to force recovery.
